Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Econometric Methods for Models with Clustered Data and Covariate-Adaptive Randomization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research that will develop new statistical theories and methods for analyzing three different kinds of data that are used to test economic theories. The first project considers how to analyze data when the individual data points can be grouped into a small number of "clusters". Since statistical methods begin with assumptions about randomization, the PI team will develop a theory of randomization tests that work in these settings. The second project considers problems associated with using randomized controlled methods to test the effects of an intervention, policy, or technology. These methods generally involve assigning people to a treatment or control group based on complicated rules that are designed to assure the two groups are comparable. These rules have implications for the best ways to analyze the resulting data, and the PIs plan to develop a new method that takes this into account. Finally, the team will consider how to best develop a method that can combine several separate statistical tests into a single framework. The project advances science by developing new methods that will be used to test theories from economics and other social sciences.

The PIs pursue three different projects in econometrics. First, in joint work with Joseph Romano, they will develop a theory of randomization tests under an approximate symmetry assumption. A leading example where approximate symmetry holds is settings in which the data can be grouped into a small number of clusters. The hope is that their new methodology will work well in such settings, for which inference is known to be challenging. Second, in joint work with Federico Bugni, they will study how complicated treatment assignment rules designed to balance baseline covariates across treatment and control groups impacts inference about the average treatment effect. In preliminary work, they have shown that the usual two-sample t-test can be quite conservative in such settings. We plan to develop methods that do not have this feature. Finally, in joint work with Andres Santos, the PIs will develop methods for testing unions of functional moment inequalities. This framework encompasses many problems that have so far been treated separately in the econometrics literature, including (subvector) inference for (conditional) moment inequalities and tests of stochastic dominance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal has produced several published papers on the topic of inference methods for experiments with covariate-adaptive randomization and on the topic of inference methods for models with clustered data. The main outcomes within each of these areas can be summarized as follows.

 
In a randomized controlled trial (RCT) researchers first use a mechanism to assign participants into one of several treatments and then proceed to analyze the collected data using statistical tests. We studied the properties of commonly used tests in RCTs that employ covariate information at the time of assignment to treatment (that is, a particular mechanism to assign participants into treatments). Our main findings were that most of those commonly used tests are approximately conservative under covariate-adaptive randomization, and that some are even invalid. After presenting a series of negative results about the performance of commonly used tests, our second main finding was to show that all of these tests can be properly modified to deliver new tests that are approximately valid and exact. We provided a correction for each of the tests we studied (two sample t-test, permutation tests, regression with strata fixed effects, and saturated regressions) and compared their relative properties using a newly developed theory. The modified versions of the tests we proposed are easy to implement, but we have also developed publicly available statistical software to facilitate the adoption of the new methods we proposed. 


In much of modern empirical analysis the data available to researchers consist of units that can be naturally grouped into ``clusters'', where units within a cluster may influence each other but may not easily influence units in other clusters. For example, students may be grouped by schools, citizens of a country may be grouped by cities, and firms may by grouped by industry. In this proposal we focused on situations where there is a large number of units but few of such groupings or clusters. We then studied the properties of the wild bootstrap (a popular inference method for clustered data) and proposed a new approximate randomization inference method. We showed that there are conditions under which the popular wild bootstrap method is approximately valid. However, one of those conditions requires the clusters to be homogeneous (that is, the clusters should be relatively similar to each other in terms of features we observe about them), which renders the method inapplicable in settings with cluster heterogeneity (a situation that commonly arises in practice). Therefore, while our results provided the first formal results to guarantee the validity of the wild bootstrap when the number of clusters is small, they also highlighted an important limitation of this popular approach. We then developed a new inference method that is shown to be approximately valid under arbitrary heterogeneity of the clusters (that is, clusters are now allowed to be distinct in arbitrary ways). The new method exploited a theory of approximate randomization tests that, in itself, proved to be quite useful to study other problems (for example, in the context of the so-called regression discontinuity design). This new method is easy to implement and provides an improvement over the popular wild bootstrap approach. Finally, we have developed publicly available statistical software to facilitate its adoption by applied researchers.
